ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I developed my essaywriting, presentation, and research skills. Gained a thorough and comprehensive understanding of Spenser's works.

I learned about Elizabethan history, the life of Edmund Spenser, and the intricacies of his work, The Faerie Queene. I also improved my writing and researching skills and practiced my close reading skills with weekly discussion posts.
I learned more about critical discourse on Edmund Spenser!
We became deeply familiar with Edmund Spenser and his massive work The Faerie Queene!

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths:
- I really enjoyed the discussion format. Out of all the classes I've taken at Yale, this class incorporated student engagement and thought the most. Really enjoyed the experience and kept me immersed.
- Strong, informative PPTs and class organization in general
- Professor extremely knowledgeable and gave in-depth feedback

Strengths: I like how it focused primarily on TFQ but expanded out to Spensers other works at the end of the class; the weekly discussion posts were helpful in keeping track of where we were in the text and covering a variety of topics; I really liked how our discussions were always based on the discussion posts because it meant that at least one person was always interested by the question which kept the discussion lively

Weaknesses: the reading load was very high, but Im not sure how this could be helped because TFQ is so long.

The teaching was rather uninspired. Professor Sarpong clearly knows a lot about the material and time period but she never really shared that with us. It was just long block quotes from other scholars and our own meandering questions that were read aloud. I would suggest taking a different course for Renaissance credit.

I feel that the discussion question and answer felt sort of stilted, and it made each class mechanical.

Professor Sarpong has great knowledge about Spenser, canonical and newer approaches to his writings.

The strength of this course was its small seminar format. With our thorough reading responses due each week, we had the ability to guide the class discussions to suit our interests within the text! Dr. Sarpong also always assembled excellent PowerPoint that very astutely anticipated much of the questions/confusion the class would have with the text. Regarding weaknesses, the seminar format was always the same, which got a bit tedious as the semester went on.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes -- if and only if the idea of really investing yourself in the Faerie Queene is interesting and exciting to you. It is an incredibly rewarding text to invest yourself in (and surprisingly funny and fascinating and readable) but it is a very long and difficult book, and it is basically the entire class. The reading is heavy throughout, but the additional workload is relatively light until the last few weeks, which are consumed with the final paper. The paper was a challenge that I hadn't really anticipated, but one I ended up loving -- made me feel much more connected to the text, and ready and excited to write my thesis even though my thesis is not about anything remotely similar to the Faerie Queene.
Yes! The information is fascinating, and it's presented very well. You will learn a lot and have fun too!
I would cautiously recommend this course. It was very niche but what I found great about it was that it was as much a history course as an English course, which was super interesting to me.
I would not. Felt disrespectful to the material.

I took this class as a Renaissance credit, and found it to be satisfactory. I personally wouldnt take another Elizabethan era class again, since my interests lie elsewhere, but this was a great intro course.
I would recommend this course! It is very fulfilling to conquer such a massive work like The Faerie Queene, and it was exciting to become so deeply engaged with a famous work.
